Indonesian: rekening (from Dutch – only used in the bank), akun (used in all term of account excluding bank account)
tepat, akurat influenced by Dutch accuraat
selepas, sesudah, setelah (also used in Malay to indicate consecutive actions)

Malaysian: pangsapuri, rumah pangsa, rumah kondo (only for 'condominium')
Indonesian: apartemen (influenced by Dutch appartement), rumah susun (rusun) (public housing for poor family), kondominium

Malaysian: majlis, perhimpunan (from the root verb 'himpun' meaning 'to gather/assemble')

Indonesian: Athena (influenced by Dutch Athene or from native Greek Athina)

Malaysian: makcik (also used in Riau Malay dialect in Indonesia), emak saudara, ibu saudara

Indonesian: autobiografi, otobiografi is a nonstandard spelling
otomatis (derived from Dutch pronunciation of automatisch)
belakang layar (literally "back screen/behind the screen"), belakang panggung
matras influenced by Dutch matras, tempat tidur, ranjang, kasur
baliho supposedly from English ballyhoo (in English it means extravagant publicity or fuss) papan iklan, papan reklame from Dutch reclame (advertisement)
miliar (from Dutch miljard), milyar (informal but frequently used)
Inggris, Britania (influenced by Dutch Brittannië but it is rarely used)
bus, bis nonstandard, influenced by Dutch pronunciation
terminal bus ( frequently pronounced as terminal bis as it is derived from Dutch pronunciation of bus )
pemberhentian bus, halte bus from Dutch bushalte

Malaysian: kereta (means carriage in Indonesian, commonly used as a shorthand for kereta api, which means train. Malay followed English derivation of car which was a contraction of horseless carriage)

Indonesian: kasir, from Dutch kassier juru uang(rare)
sensus, cacah, banci (virtually never used in Indonesia, listed by KBBI)

Malaysian: cili, lada ('pepper' in Indonesian), cabai (used in the northern states of Malaysia)

Indonesian: Tionghoa (standard term for Chinese people), Tiongkok (Republik Rakyat Tiongkok: official name of the People's Republic of China), Cina (standard, still in common use but discouraged due to possible racist connotations. See Shina for further information.), China (nonstandard)

Malaysian: panggung wayang bergambar (more popularly abbreviated as pawagam), panggung wayang

Indonesian: kota , bandar (a city in the sea shore or port city in Indonesian)

Malaysian: awam (In Indonesian, it means "not expert"), sivil
penjernihan (to make something, e.g. water, clear in Indonesian)
fasal (equivalent term in Indonesian is pasal)

Indonesian: lipas, kecoa from the Chinese Min Nan ka chuah
ulasan (can be including review, interpretation and comment), komentar (from Dutch commentaar)
perusahaan, firma, maskapai (from Dutch maatschappij – almost exclusively used to refer to airline companies, i.e. maskapai penerbangan)
konfirmasi, pengesahan of a document, kepastian of a decision
undang-undang dasar (influenced by Dutch grondwet ("basic law")), konstitusi (from Dutch constitutie)
pembangunan (of building), pembinaan (of moral), konstruksi (from Dutch constructie)
korporasi (from Dutch corporatie), badan usaha, perusahaan
negara, negeri in Malaysia, negeri usually refers to a state within a federation
penjahat, kriminal, ahli pidana (ahli pidana is criminal law expert)
saat ini, kini, terkini, aktual (from Dutch actueel)

Malaysian: langsir (In Indonesian, langsir is train wagon arrangement.), tirai

Indonesian: pabean refers to the administrative institution, bea dan cukai (bea-cukai) lit. tariff-and-tax, duty
demokratis (from Dutch demokratisch note: "democratic republic" (in country names) translates as republik demokratik, such as in Republik Demokratik Kongo (Democratic Republic of the Congo))
direktur from Dutch (and French) directeur, sutradara (of a film) from Sanskrit (through Javanese), pengarah (for an event)
diskon, rabat, potongan harga, korting from Dutch, less frequent
sopir from French chauffeur through Dutch, pengemudi formal

narkoba (an acronym for NARKotika dan OBat-obatan terlArang (narcotics and illegal drugs)), NAPZA (less frequent – an acronym for NArkotika, Psikotropika dan Zat-zat Adiktif (narcotics, psychotropics, and addictive chemical substances))
surel (standard, shortened of surat elektronik (electronic mail)), email (rarely used in everyday spelling, often used on online spelling (e.g. website-based registration or social account))

Malaysian: Easter, Paskah strictly used for Jewish Passover

Indonesian: editor, penyunting, redaktur (from French rédacteur through Dutch – refers to editors of mass printed media)
Hari Raya Idulfitri – Idul Fitri nonstandard spelling, but common, Lebaran colloquial – from Javanese

Malaysian: lapan used as colloquial abbreviation in Indonesian
Indonesian: delapan used in Malaysia before the spelling reform

Malaysian: sekatan (In Indonesian, it means "obstacle" or "room which separated with partition")
kecemasan (used for anxiety or "too anxious" (condition) in Indonesian.)
Indonesian: darurat (from Arabic – also used in Malaysia to express a state of emergency), kegawatan
knalpot (from Dutch, in which it also means "muffler")
paparan, ekspos, pendedahan (virtually never used in Indonesia, listed by KBBI)
padam (of flame or light), punah (of species), pupus (loss of hope)

column4: Indonesians always use the plural form.

Indonesian: pemadam kebakaran (lit. fire extinguisher), branwir (from Dutch brandweer (fire defense))

Malaysian: tingkat may be used in Indonesian to express the number of storeys/levels a building has, e.g. a 5-storey building = gedung bertingkat 5, or to emphasize British floor numbering, e.g. tingkat satu means first floor (UK), second floor (US) in both languages, aras (used to emphasize American floor numbering, e.g. aras dua = tingkat satu
Indonesian: lantai also refers to floor as ground surface in both languages, emphasizes American floor numbering, tingkat emphasizes British floor numbering, e.g. lantai dua = tingkat satu
fungi (commonly has got misconception as: jamur)

Malaysian: perabot rumah, perkakas rumah (In Indonesian, perkakas means equipment.)
Indonesian: mebel from Dutch meubelen, perabot rumah tangga, furnitur
geng, preman from Dutch vrijman (lit. free-man), gangster from English
roda gigi influenced by Dutch tandwiel, literally "tooth wheel"
persneling from Dutch versnelling, girboks, transmisi
stik golf, pemukul golf, tongkat golf

Malaysian: kerajaan derived from raja (king) – used in Malaysia and Brunei – in Indonesian means "kingdom"
Indonesian: pemerintah derived from perintah (order/instruction) – also used in Singapore, which, like Indonesia, is a republic

Malaysian: gabenor, Yang di-Pertua Negeri (in Malaysian states)

Indonesian: kelompok, grup from Dutch pronunciation of groep, (per)kumpulan, (per)himpunan
jaminan, garansi from Dutch pronunciation of garantie

Malaysian: ibu pejabat "ibu" also means "mother" or "ma'am" in both languages.

Indonesian: kerudung, jilbab though these words have different meaning
jamu often understood as traditional potion made from rhizomes, also means "guest" ("tamu") and "treat the guest" ("menjamu")., herbal
rumah sakit influenced by Dutch ziekenhuis ("house of the sick") – This term is still used in Brunei, but in Malaysia, "hospital" has replaced the term completely since the 1960s.
Hungaria, Hongaria substandard, influenced by Dutch Hongarije
impotensi from Dutch impotentie, lemah syahwat colloquial
informasi, from Dutch informatie, penerangan rare
internasional, mancanegara from Javanese meaning: foreign land)
warnet an acronym for "WARung interNET" (literally: internet shop)

Malaysian: penyerangan, penjajahan (means colonialism in Indonesian), invasi
kicap (Indonesian equivalent, kecap, means soy sauce.)
Indonesian: saus tomat from French sauce tomate
advokat from Dutch advocaat, pengacara (means 'master of ceremony' in Malay.)

Malaysian: perundangan (In Indonesian, it means legislation.), legislatif

Indonesian: Lisboa from Portuguese, Lisabon influenced by Dutch Lissabon
hakim from Arabic ????? – used in Malaysian to refer to judges, magistrat less common

Malaysian: lelaki, laki-laki, jantan (for animals, depending on the context, it can mean masculine or used as a derogatory term on men)
Indonesian: laki-laki, pria, lelaki, jantan (on animals, used on men to describe masculinity)
matematika, ilmu hitung, ilmu hisab only used in Islamic text book
militer (from French militaire through Dutch militair), kemiliteran, ketentaraan
sepeda motor lit. "motorized bicycle" – influenced by Dutch motorfiets, motor (informal)

Malaysian: surat khabar coined from two Arabic words: ??rat – ???? / ???? (form, appearance) and khabar ??? (news)
Indonesian: surat kabar (more formal – lit. news letter), koran (from French courant through Dutch, become Krant in modern Dutch, but Koerant in Afrikaans)

Malaysian: bising, kecoh in Indonesian means "disturb" or "distract", memekak

Indonesian: angka, nomor – nomer substandard spelling from Dutch/German nummer
perawat, suster from Dutch zuster, only for female nurse
samudra, lautan rarely used in formal situation

Malaysian: pegawai, kaki tangan (a negative connotation usually means accomplice in criminal activity in Indonesian)
pesakit In Indonesian, this means convict

Indonesian: patroli (for police and military) (from Dutch patrolie), ronda (for civilian)

Malaysian: jalan pinggir, jalur jalan untuk pejalan kaki, laluan jalan kaki, kaki lima (In Indonesia, it is used in pedagang kaki lima (street vendor).)
zakar from Arabic ????? "male"- this word is extremely vulgar in Indonesian, "buah zakar" means testicles, batang lelaki, konek (slang)
Indonesian: penis(formal), zakarfrom Arabic, less frequent, pelir, alat kelamin laki-laki(euphemism), kemaluan lelaki(euphemism), burung (vulgar), titit (children's slang like "pee-pee"), kontol (slang, extremely vulgar)
persen, perseratus(less common, usually used when compared per mille)
apotek (from Dutch apotheek), farmasi (usually for medicine manufacturers)

Malaysian: gambar (In Indonesian, it means "picture" or "figure".), foto
fizik (Indonesian equivalent term, fisik, is used for term physical, e.g. aktivitas fisik (physical activity).)

Indonesian: copet (contraction of colong dompet- wallet thief), pencopet
bajak laut, perompak (perompak in Malay, means "robber"), lanun(archaic)
salat(standard), shalat, sholat (from Arabic, 'sh' is usually pronounced as 's'), sembahyang
surau, musala, mushollah (from Arabic, 'sh' is usually pronounced as 's')

Malaysian: mengandung, hamil (formal, from Arabic ??????), berbadan dua lit. "two bodied", bunting for animals
Sendirian Berhad abbreviated as Sdn Bhd (suffix), "sendirian" alone means "alone"

Indonesian: produk (from English and Dutch product), hasil, keluaran more specific term for outcome
pelacur, Wanita Tuna Susila (WTS) (Sanskrit, pronounced 'way-tay-es', i.e. "moral-less women"), Pekerja Seks Komersial (PSK) (formal, pronounced 'pay-es-ka' (commercial sex workers)), perek (slang)

Malaysian: wilayah (used in Indonesian to mean 'area'), daerah (used in Indonesian to mean 'area')

tolak (It used as in tolak peluru (shot put) in Indonesian for this contex, used less primarily in Indonesian to mean 'subtract', it also means 'to refuse/reject', also common meaning in Malay when used in arithmetics)
Indonesian: dorong (means "to push" in Malay, but often used to mean "to support")
kuitansi, kwitansi (substandard, from Dutch kwitantie), resi, bon from Dutch, struk

Malaysian: pergerakan (In Indonesian, it means "movement".), pengambilan (In Indonesian, it means "taking".)
peti sejuk lit. cool box (rarely used in Indonesian)
Indonesian: lemari es, lemari pendingin(literally means cooler closet) , kulkas (from Dutch koelkast)

Malaysian: kajian(mean research or investigation result in Indonesian)

Indonesian: rumah makan lit. "eating house", warung makan lit. "eating café", restoran

Malaysian: bilik (usually used to mean "compartment" in Indonesian)
Indonesian: kamar (from Dutch kamer), ruang (Javanese, for storage areas etc.)

Malaysian: bulatan e.g. Bulatan DBP in Kuala Lumpur pusing keliling (in Brunei)
Indonesian: bundaran e.g. Bundaran HI in Jakarta
kerajaan (in Malaysia and Brunei means "kingdom" or "government")

Malaysian: getah may also mean gum or sap or resin in both languages, also figure of speech for "cause of bad deed"

Indonesian: rumor, desas-desus, kabar angin, kabar burung

Malaysian: saluran najis "najis" means dirty in both languages, saluran kumbahan
Indonesian: selokan, parit (means 'ditch' in Malay), got, saluran air/pembuangan

Malaysian: syampu (from Anglo-Indian / Hindustani ch?mpo, the imperative form of (Hindi) ??????? ch?mpn? 'to smear, knead the muscles, massage')
berkongsi (In Indonesian, it means "creating trading company" or "ploting something bad".)
baju (also in Indonesian but more generally refers to clothes)
Indonesian: kaos, kemeja (from Portuguese camisa, implies collared shirt)

Malaysian: kasut generalized term for any footwear in Indonesian, but usually related to sandals or ancient shoes., sepatu
Indonesian: sepatu (understood but less frequently used in Malaysia, from Portuguese sapato)

Malaysian: tapak (mean foundation (building) or footprint in Indonesia)

Indonesian: sodomi, liwat (only used in Islamic text book)
asam, masam (poetic, usually used in connotative expression: bermuka masam: sour faced (unsatisfied/unhappy expression))

Malaysian: berbicara, bercakap (means 'to chat' in Indonesian), bersembang, berborak

Indonesian: spesialis (in case of specialist doctor), pakar in general, it means expert
olahraga (means "athletics" Malay, from Sanskrit, lit. "to train the body")

Malaysian: pasangan suami-isteri, kelamin colloquial, in Indonesian means "sex" or "gender"
kakitangan (phrase "kaki tangan" mean subordinate with negative image in Indonesian)
Indonesian: staf, personil from Dutch personeel, pegawai
bodoh, dungu, tolol, goblok (slang), very demeaning in Malay, geblek (slang), bego (slang)
Minggu from Portuguese Domingo which means Lord's Day, Ahad(only used in Islamic calendar

Malaysian: cermin mata gelap (In Indonesia, cermin means "mirror".)
Indonesian: kacamata hitam (lit. black glasses), kacamata riben (from American brand of sunglasses 'Ray-Ban')
supermarket, pasar swalayan(literally mean self-service market)

Malaysian: tinjauan (mean process or result of observation in Indonesian), kaji selidik

Indonesian: air keran (from Dutch Kraan), air ledeng ("ledeng" also means "plumbing", from Dutch "leiding")

Malaysian: ubi kayu as in Indonesian, understood as the tuber cassava itself
ustaz, ustad (ultimately from Persian ???????), ustadzah female
pasukan used in Indonesian to refer to squad (military)

Indonesian: testis, biji kemaluan, buah zakar (slang, vulgar), kanjut (slang, vulgar)
Thailand, Siam, Muangthai used in old scripts
tiket, karcis (from Dutch kaartje. Usually refers to small-size ticket)
waktu from Arabic ????? (al-Waqt), masa (can be used for 'at a specific long period of time' in Indonesian)
toilet, kamar kecil, WC (pronounced 'we-se') for watercloset

Malaysian: lampu isyarat (In Indonesian, isyarat means sign.)

Indonesian: transportasi, pengangkutan, perhubungan (in case of Ministry of Transportation)
transseksual, waria (polite) a shortened form of wanita-pria , bencong, banci

Malaysian: pokok in Indonesian means "principal" or "core" or "staple", in Sundanese poko means authentic, e.g. authentic cuisine, pohon

column4: starting with 1012, Indonesian uses the short scale.)

Malaysian: pusing (means 'to spin' in Indonesian, commonly used to mean dizzy as a short form of kepala pusing), belok

Indonesian: paman, oom, om (derived from Dutch, pronounced and sometimes spelt as oom)

English: United States of America (USA) United States (US)

Malaysian: faraj (from Arabic, in Indonesian means "vulva"), pepek/pepet (slang)
Indonesian: alat kelamin wanita, liang peranakan, vagina, farji, memek (slang, vulgar), pepek (slang, vulgar)
kata kerja (influenced by Dutch werkwoord, literally "work word"), verba
sangat, amat, sekali, banget (from Javanese ngoko)
wisata, kunjungan, pelancongan, lawatan (to foreign country, sick person or dead person)
kawat (e.g. copper wire), kabel (e.g. electrical wire, cable)

Malaysian: anda (very formal), awak, kamu, engkau, kau
Indonesian: anda (everyday formal), kamu (familiar only), engkau ('kau) (prose), elu/loe (very vulgar Betawi slang, influenced by Chinese dialect leu)

Malaysian: zoo, taman haiwan (kebun binatang was also frequently used in Malaysia before the mid-1960s)
Indonesian: kebun binatang (derived from Dutch dierentuin, literally "animal garden"), taman margasatwa (more formal form for zoological park)
